Reviews.Title: Very Nice Camera ... works great!
Reviews.Author: Richard Boyd
Reviews.Content: This is the third Hootoo PTZ camera I have bought and installed in my home security system. I also have a Foscam, and an Agasio. I like all three brands. The Foscam does seem to work best, but the Hootoo cameras are right there too, and seem to give the most bang for the buck. I can highly recommend this Hootoo camera to anyone thinking of getting a PTZ, pan-&-tilt, wireless ip camera.Configuring any of these little ip cameras can be a challenge to the novice. Instructions that come with them are usually written by people who do not clearly understand English. Thus, can be pretty confusing. They also depend on the user having working knowledge of wireless and wired networking. In addition to configuring the camera, the installer should know how to configure the router for reserved ip addresses on your local home network, port assignment and forwarding, and DDNS to view the cameras from phones and other remote/off-site computers.Most routers come with pre-set DDNS providers, which you will need to establish accounts with (either paid, or free) prior to configuring your router, if you intend to be viewing from remote locations outside you home network.. The cameras can also be setup independent of the router for DDNS. However, the DDNS providers the cameras are pre-set to were all in China. I would think that users in other countries might have problems with that, because when they view their home networks remotely while traveling, they would be viewing them via China. Personally, I wanted a provider with servers on my home soil and closer to home. So, I chose to use one of the DNS providers pre-set in my router, which was in my home country (the U.S.).So, before you start to configure your camera, be sure to become familiar your router, and be comfortable with making "advanced" configuration changes to it. Each router has a different look and feel (even sometimes different models made by the same company). As stated above, probably a good idea to get your account with a compatible DDNS service too, prior to starting the install.Once you know your way around your router, then connect your camera directly to the router via Ethernet cable to one of the empty LAN ports, and let the camera boot up. When it has completed it's boot, then install the software on the CD that came with this camera ... This "ip camera tool" program will find your camera and report the ip address it has been assigned by your router. Enter that address into the address window of your browser and then connect to the camera.It will ask you for a username and password. The username is "admin", and there is no password (i.e. just type "admin" as the username, and then press the "enter" key). I recommend you set your own password. Once you pass the logon, then you will be into the little web-server in the camera.The camera will show you a live streaming video of what it is seeing. I like to just play a little first. To make sure the camera does all the basics. Play with the controls, set the resolution, etc. Look at the different menus and settings you can configure.For basic wireless use, you will need to configure the SSID of your router into your camera. If you have wireless encryption set, then you will also need to program the password and encryption type (WEP, WPA). You might want to reserve an ip address (the one initially assigned is usually best) and set a port for your camera in the router at this time. Then configure those in the camera, too. Once that is done, then you should be able to remove the Ethernet cable, and reboot your camera. It will connect wirelessly. Refresh the connection in you browser. Then test it out and finish your other setups.One note on the transceiver (radio) and little 3dbi antenna that comes with. It doesn't have great range. The picture will be choppy and controls will be slow, if you have a weak radio connection between the router and camera. I replaced the little antenna on one of my cameras with a huge 9dbi to get it to work better when the camera was about 20 feet away from the router, and separated by a couple walls. I've got another Hootoo, and a Foscam in an enclosure, about 100 feet away, and have them coming in through a wireless range extender.=======================About picture quality, etc.This is a low end video camera that costs less than $100 .... If you want HD picture quality that matches your HD TV, on a ip camera that can pan and tilt, then pay the $500 (or more) for an HD, pan and tilt, ip camera, and another $300 (or more) for professional IR illumination lights!!! You get what you pay for. However, with these cameras, I've gotten my complete money's worth!I find that the picture quality for this camera is great during that day. Exactly like a low-end video camera should be. At night, the LEDs on the camera illuminate the area and return a viewable picture to about 20ft. I have had to add some IR illuminators  to the areas that I want to view better (I bought two 40-LED illuminators on Amazon, $12 ea). Also, the microphone and speakers work great. Although, they do not work with any browser, except Internet Explorer, with ActiveX (ActiveX is just a Microsoft software add-on that mimics Java). If you have ActiveX configured properly in IE, the little viewer onboard the camera works like a charm for all features, and with any of the PTZ cameras. I'm currently using one IE browser to monitor four of these cameras (two Hootoos, an Agasio, and a Foscam) ... The software is not perfect, but it's free!I also view my PTZ cameras on my Droid smartphone, and with third party video security software ... The various software and platforms work perfectly with all of the cameras.

Reviews.Title: Works great with a few small concerns.
Reviews.Author: Antonio Darnelli "tonyd999"
Reviews.Content: The product comes with everything stated - IP camera, network cable, antenna, CD, user's manual, power adapter and some drywall screws.The camera had some thin strings of glue on it - apparently from the packaging.  I couldn't easily remove the glue, so I left it on the camera.  There wasn't any glue on the lens.  The camera is about the size of a can of coca cola - so it was a little bigger than I expected.Setup was nice and easy.  I opened the CD and copied everything to my computer (MacBook Pro).  I then connected the camera (with the network cable) to my router, and started the camera software.  It easily found the camera, and after a few clicks, I was able to make the changes to the settings to match my environment.  I then disconnected it from the router and placed it on my desk.  I was able to set the camera to do motion detection and send copies via FTP of the pictures to my computer.  The software is easy enough to figure out so that I didn't even have to read the manual.The pictures are nice and fairly clear for what you would expect out of VGA (640x480).  The web interface is nice, and the camera scrolls up/down and left/right.My concerns:  On motion-detection, the camera sometimes detects motion and sometimes it does not.  However, this may be due to the sensitivity setting that I chose (5 out of 10).  And, I have the camera pointed outside, so if the wind blows the tree limbs, it will take pictures.  And, one out of every 50 images, the image will be a little messed up - where the bottom 1/3 of the picture is blank.I could not get my router to properly forward the IP address and port number to the camera, so I couldn't test it to see if I could connect to it outside of my home network.  This is probably a limitation on my router.  But, I was able to use my iPhone to connect to it inside my network, and the software worked well.  The buttons to control the camera are a bit small on an iPhone.  It also worked on my iPad, and the buttons were a little easier to control.It works well enough that I am planning on buying a couple more of these cameras.Overall, despite a few concern - but because of the price and features, I will still give it five stars.  I will come back and amend my review if I find out anything important to report.

Reviews.Title: Good outbound audio for baby monitoring. Better video under low light compared with other cameras.
Reviews.Author: New father
Reviews.Content: I recently bought several different brands of wireless IP cameras. I planed to install some for my own home and for my in-law's home. I previously compared Tenvis JPT3815W, EasyN EasyN FS-613A-M136 and HooToo HT-IP206  cameras on amazon.com. IP206 is perfect for garage door opener control after tinkering with camera settings. Excellent for those who forget to close their door or need to open the door remotely for large-item delivery. Caution: Make sure no kids or other people around the door. EasyN and HooToo have much better outbound audio for remote listening. Good for baby monitoring. All have inadequate incoming audio. Listeners next to the camera can hardly understand the words without repeating by the remote person speaking into IP Cam Viewer.  Luckily, you can phone in instead of relying on the camera if you want to speak to people next to the camera.I just got a Hootoo HT-IP210F camera. It is an upgrade from IP206. Slightly more expensive. If you are comfortable playing with your router settings, you can set up these cameras in a few minutes. Since I have done this before, so it is no brainer for me. Hooked it up to my router with RJ45 ethernet cable. Easily found the LAN IP for 210F on my PC (wirelessly linked to the same router) using the finding camera software from Hootoo (other vendor's camera finder software likely works as well). Entered its LAN IP address in my Google Chrome browser and I saw the web control interface and camera view right away. From the interface you can set up WiFi password to link to your router wirelessly without a cable. 210F will reboot. Unplug the RJ45 cable. Surprisingly you won't see your camera using the previous LAN IP. This is because 210F gets a different IP for WiFi connection! Not the same as your wired connection IP. You can find the WiFi IP if you view your router's LAN connections based on your camera's MAC. If you stick to this wireless IP. No further change needed. To have the same IP for your wired and WiFi connections, you need to set up your camera from its web interface using fixed LAN IP instead of DHCP. Both 206 and 210F have very good audio heard from Android client (IP Cam Viewer app). There is some background noise. When you turn the volume down on your Android phone a little, you barely notice it.  You can clearly and continuously people hear speaking in the room. Definitely good as a baby monitor. Perhaps slightly better than IP206. I am very pleased. My Tenvis JPT3815W is noisy and the outgoing audio keeps breaking up. You can hardly hear a continuous sentence. Not good as a baby monitor. All these cameras perform poorly for incoming audio. The speakers are tiny inside the cameras. Not loud at all. The audio keeps breaking up. Thus, plugging an external speaker may increase the volume, but not the audio quality. Picture qualities are equality good for all these cameras because they have the same resolution. IP210F has more IR lights and IR cut. The IR cut function works well by removing color distortion due to IR in sunlight. Thus, red is red and green is green, etc. You will see a difference when you compare a camera without this function. This function is not for the IR lighting condition under low/no light. Under darkness, all these cameras show washed-out black and white colors with IR lighting.It turns out that this 210F camera has a new firmware (Version 17.37.2.47). By default, it closes (i.e., connects) pin 1 and pin 2 constantly during use. You can change the Alarm Service Settings so it won't do so. However, during booting, pin 1 and pin 2 will close for a couple of seconds. This will trigger the garage door opener! No matter what I do with the alarm services settings, I cannot avoid this. 206 with firmware  17.37.2.41 does not have this problem. This same version is shared by 206 and 210F. I guess if you downgrade the firmware, you will make your 210F work just like 206. I never tried because .47 firmware is not yet available for download from hootoo.com. I need a backup before I am willing to give it a try.People are talking about using a spare Android phone as IP cam. I have two working like this also. However, they cannot be compared with any of these wireless IP cameras. You see nothing using Android under low light, but you can see a dark room with IP cameras having IR light bulbs. Of cause it is very nice to be able to pan and tilt. 210F is slightly more expensive. It is also slightly bulkier in size. 210F has 18 IR lights, 8 more than 206's 10 lights.  When IR lights switch on, there is clicking sound from the relay inside (206 does not have this sound). There is a blinking green light inside the casing (not the indicating light next to those IR light bulbs). It leaks out from the vents under the camera. It may bother you if you place the camera next to bed side. 210F has a wider pan angle (320 degrees v. 270 degrees for 206). All the cameras I tested can be viewed using IP Cam Viewer Android app by selecting. For Hootoo cameras, select Hootoo/Hootoo IP camera.  You can remotely pan, tilt and reboot the IP cameras. 210F has an extra mic socket for an external mic while 206 has only a slot for an external speaker. In all, I am very satisfied with 210F. I use 206 to control my garage door. When I open my garage door, I can view and hear the street traffic remotely. I can hear bird chirping outside and cars passing by. I place 210F in the kitchen. If I do need 210F to control my garage, I think downgrading the firmware will do the trick. I played with motion detection and e-mail, ftp notification. Worked like charm. You can use smtp.gmail.com as mail server with your Gmail login name/password. The problem is that if your camera views too much activity, you get too many e-mails. Thus, after playing, I turned this off. You don't really need DNS server. There is a function in 210F to send an e-mail to your notifying you its current external IP address and port number when it boots. In the US, I have the same IP for years with Roadrunner cable modem service. It never changed even after a long power outage that lasted several days in the Midwest last year.  I also have localphone.com VoIP service. From my account web access with the Localphone, I can see my home router IP address used by my registered IP phone. 210F does come with its vendor provided DNS. I never need it anyway. For all the IP cameras I tested, I see mostly black and white colors at night with IR. This is enough for me. All these cameras have reddish IR lights that turn on automatically under low light. You will notice the reddish lights. Hopefully, babies won't be attracted to them. They all have quiet motors that are hardly audible by people a few feet away from the cameras, unless they pay attention.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Value With Great Support!
Reviews.Author: Martin A Hogan "Marty From SF"
Reviews.Content: For the price, this security camera is a very cool item. It can be installed on a flat or vertical surface and comes with a lot of camera options, like view-ability from anywhere in the world from a PC, laptop, iPhone or iPad. It can be set to several different stable angles and there is a tiny speaker for recording or sending sound (I turned mine off). Once set up, you can also remotely pan and tilt the lens to any position. The pan/tilt speeds range from 1 to 10 and there are 15 preset positions for viewing. When motion is detected, it sends an email with a half dozen shots to your account. I set up a separate email account just for this camera so I wouldn't have my regular email overloaded. Note that you need to set the sensitivity of motion to 1 through 10. Having cats, I set it to a low sensitivity. The image is sufficient (640 X 580) and it has `Upgraded Night Vision' with 16 Built-in IR Illuminators. The IR Cut Filter eliminates washed-out or odd or glaring colors.Setup was tough for me, although I noticed other reviewers felt it was easy. I found setup was not intuitive. The instructions that came in the box were very small, so I printed out a larger set. At first, I had trouble and you need to know your router password (write it on the bottom of your router for future use) and mail account passwords. No sweat. I called support and they were on it! In a relatively short period of time, support (through LOGMEIN) was able to teach me how to set up all the features and how to use them properly. The toughest part was writing down the instructions that were relevant to me. It was touch and go initially, but we got it and now I am happy to know I can reset this camera if I need to without support. Do note that support was from California and they were friendly and patient. That was a huge seller for me.There were some interesting things I discovered about this camera. It should be used for indoor use over outdoor (they do manufacture outdoor cameras). Initially I had my set in a windowsill overlooking my front door, but the day images were frequently emailed to me (it detected little movements of shrubbery). I simply lowered the sensitivity. Then the night photos were glaring white. It turns out that the infra-red camera reflected on my window, causing that. I moved it indoor to view towards my sliding glass door and windows. Now when it discovers motion, I get an email to my account within a minute. Even if a burglar saw the camera and stole it (you have the option to turn of the infra-red light), they would be photographed and stored in the memory. Check with your insurance carrier. Some will give you a discount depending on how many cameras and what types you own.I plan on getting another camera soon and the good news is the software is already setup for my PC and devices. All you need is an electrical socket. I'd give it five stars, but I found the instructions to be tough to read and understand - that's a user comment. Otherwise, this is a valuable addition to your home. This product was generously supplied by the manufacturer for an honest review.

Reviews.Title: good little device
Reviews.Author: dk
Reviews.Content: Great bang for the buck device. Bought 2 originally to test, and bought 2 more for other areas of the house. Motion detection, Night vision, email alert, PTZ work. It may be seem a little quirky at first and the instruction booklet may be small, but it works. The first 2 cameras took a little over an hour to set up completely. This includes router configurations and my phone app. I am an IT guy though.

Reviews.Title: Easy to setup and use IP internet Camera
Reviews.Author: ISOcrazy "MPL"
Reviews.Content: I was not expecting much at this price point but to my surprise this turned out to be a very easy to setup and use internet IP camera. I did not even had to read instruction to setup except forwarding video through my home router to internet that was pretty straight forward procedure. After setup using my laptop I mostly use this with my iPhone using "Live Cam Pro APP" I downloaded from Apple APP store. It work well with my I phone and iPad so I can keep eye on my house when I travel. Night vision works well with IR LED'd automatically activating when light level is low. I have also tested motion detection that works well after adjusting sensitivity few times. It send me a email with photos when motion is detected in front of the camera. I think this is good value for money and it is good looking too with its bright white color that blend with my walls so I don't have to hide it.

Reviews.Title: Awesome, cheap camera
Reviews.Author: H. Butusov
Reviews.Content: First off, read the reviews. Don't bother with the CD, because you can set it up without using it.Second, if you do not know how to view what IP addresses are assigned to your DHCP devices, find a computer geek to help you set this up. Or just google it (learning is great!) If neither of those are an option for you, move along.You're checking this product out because it's $70 and says it can do a whole bunch of fancy things. You might also notice that it appears to have a bunch of engrish all over the description, so, while I personally haven't had any issues in the first hour of using it, I wouldn't doubt some of the lower-starred reviews claiming to have issues.The Good;-If you read the reviews that say, "hook up the power and ethernet, grab the DHCP address, enter the default username of admin and no password, then start configuring" (and all that makes sense to you), you can have this thing configured in a matter of minutes. I also grabbed filezilla server and set up FTP transfer on motion detection in around 5-10 minutes.-Responsive interface for browsers that aren't IE-WiFi setup had me scared for a second, but you have to unplug the ethernet for it to start actually using that interface.The Bad;-Colour is way off (was indoors with blinds barely keeping sunlight at bay.) Assuming the IR filter was on.-No way to turn off the manufacturer's DDNS service (good incentive to change the default login information)-The alarm scheduler is horrific. I couldn't click and drag to select multiple boxes in Chrome, so I had to double click to select 4 block increments (set my cam up to alarm 24/7 if motion was detected)-If you're looking to get this specifically because it says, "Built-in audio support for two-way communication", that's exactly where it stops. It's supported via the built-in speaker and microphone jacks that you need to connect your own equipment to. Haven't tried this yet.The Weird;-It appears to have rebooted itself within the past hour of me configuring it, but I don't remember doing anything that would have made it do that.-If it does reboot, it doesn't return to the last position it was in.-Couldn't get email (via gmail account) set up in 5 minutes, so I abandoned it for FTP.-Upload interval on the alarm page doesn't appear to make any sense. Haven't bothered to google to see if there's a good explanation of what that setting actually does (there are a few settings like this - some tips in the web interface could go a long way.)

Reviews.Title: Great cam,  wish I could disable IR
Reviews.Author: Justin Bartley
Reviews.Content: This cam would get 5 stars if I could turn of the IR lights like I can on my foscam.  When trying to view through a glass the IR reflection makes it impossible to see much of anything at night.  The motion detection works great and sends me 6 pictures to a gmail account upon motion.

Reviews.Title: Great value, solid customer service
Reviews.Author: James Li
Reviews.Content: We are rapidly on our third HooToo camera and run a home network to keep track of our own animals and areas around our home. Two of the three are the indoor HT-IP210Fs and the third is a fixed outdoor HooToo. All installed easily using identical software and setups. We relied heavily on the other Amazon reviews to make setup (particularly the WiFi and port reassignments for internet viewing) go smoothly.As other reviewers noted as well, the cameras can be focused. Doing this on two of the cameras significantly improved our image quality.We use the iDevice app "IP Cam Viewer" to view our three feeds either using the LAN (which does not use up any of our limited internet bandwidtch) or the Internet (when we are not at home). This has been superior to other apps (including one that HooToo customer support recommended), and we liberally use the presets as well as panning controls on the app, preferring them to the browser-based controls (which don't always work).Because two of our cameras are quite a distance from our house (including one in a duck shed), we connected them to two small solar charging arrays (with DC volt controllers to run 5VDC to the cams) so they would run without requiring AC or house line connections. One of our three is hardwired to our Ethernet backbone while the other two use our WiFi (including an Apple Airport Express serving as a bridge to extend coverage to the animal pens).We had one of the three cameras fail early on in its lifespan (2 months). On careful inspection, an internal motor screw and possibly one of the power wires to the main board had come loose. I was able to remount both using jewelers tools and the camera came back on line.We liked the uniformity in software, the built in dynamic DNS cam-dedicated websites, and the sound monitoring features the best. We're looking at the new outdoor night-IR pan-tilt-zoom next and trying to figure out how to run power out 200 feet from our home to put it up in a field.For the price, these cameras are a great deal. We know others who've spend thousands of dollars on similar technology without much (if any) improvement in functionality.

Reviews.Title: Great value, nice features, easy setup/use
Reviews.Author: Prepper1
Reviews.Content: Bought this one to use as a baby monitor.  Paired it with Sighthound's software.  Setup was quick and easy.  Day/Night images were pretty clear for VGA resolution.  Being a WiFi camera, it is convenient and easy to move around for various applications.  Would buy again.

Reviews.Title: Sends your video to the Manufacturer
Reviews.Author: Shawn M.
Reviews.Content: I'm great with tech, and this camera is difficult to set-up. It randomly cuts out audio and/or video. Wifi works sometimes, but not always. The software I've used with it on my smartphone tends to lag, and get worse the longer you watch.My biggest complaint is that it streams video to the manufacturer (DDNS), and there is no way to disable the feature.

Reviews.Title: Very difficult setup
Reviews.Author: Cliff Hess
Reviews.Content: You are kidding right? How could this thing get so many great reviews. I am very technically knowledgeable and do all my companies IT stuff. I followed all instructions to a tee, which by the way is not easy to do as it is quite confusing. Even instructions as simple as how to install the software are horrible. They call out the wrong folders to look in. Wrong name for the software. Even wrong name for the camera. Their software initially locked up my PC and took several reboots to recover. I spent an hour on the phone with their tech support and they could not get the software to load correctly either even though they remotely logged on to my PC, but we were able to finally get the camera installed and could access it via IP address after many tries.  How anyone can send out a product with such incredibly horrible instructions and software I cannot imagine.  My only fear is that all IP cameras are going to be similarly difficult to set up as they are all made in China!  The only good things I can say are that so far the hardware works well and their technical support personnel are very patient and try hard.

Reviews.Title: Doesn't work as advertized
Reviews.Author: Sandra Sanchez
Reviews.Content: I primarily purchased this to use the two way communication option. Turns out it won't work with a MAC or Windows 8. As that's all I have the camera just works as a camera, one that is way to difficult to set up. Not impossible just harder than it really should be. I also own cameras by logitech and D-link, those were easier to install and accomplish the very same task. I can also use the internet to check the other cameras from anywhere. Could not do that with this one, I could only see it within my house.

Reviews.Title: great camera for the money...Not so great software.
Reviews.Author: Derek Mullens
Reviews.Content: The software to manage the camera is awful. You must use xp and a really old browser. The camera itself is nice though.

Reviews.Title: cheap,  both in quality and price.
Reviews.Author: Joshua M Haubold
Reviews.Content: This is a decent camera for the money, when it works. I bought three of them for baby monitors, a year later only one still works. The first one died within two months, the second at about 10 months. They're cheap, that's really all they have going for them.

Reviews.Title: decent camera, very difficult to setup but helpful seller
Reviews.Author: C. Dinan
Reviews.Content: Another update - The seller saw my review, contacted me, issued a refund and is going to provide technical support in getting a camera setup.  They seem very responsive and customer focused.Update - the software is awful and this camera is very hard to setup.  It is crappy software that does not work with Windows 8 or Windows 7 640bit.  I had to borrow a Windows XP machine to set it up and now the wifi functionality does not work.Original - I bought this to test because I need 5 or so cameras for security purposes.  Once the camera is setup the picture is good and it is easy to control from your desktop.  The documentation that comes with the camera is not good.  The support that you get from the HooToo email support desk is weak.  They would offer me suggestions that completely ignored what my email told them did not work.  The support pages from the HooToo web site offer advice like this, " HooToo models usually don't deal well with long/complex (with symbols or accents) SSID's and shared keys, so keep them simple and short"  They don't tell you in the documentation or give you warnings not to use symbols.  I used a symbol and it basically disabled my admin account forcing me to start over.  Also, I am using security software that made it impossible to setup the HooToo camera, so I had to borrow a laptop with weaker security software on it to get this thing setup.

Reviews.Title: Camera works well. Beware the multi-step set up required for internet viewing, and very heavy RF interference.
Reviews.Author: P. Pointer
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for monitoring a small room where a pet is kept when no one is home.  We wanted both in-home and external viewing of the real time video, using tablets and telephones.  This camera is definitely capable of addressing those needs.I found the setup to be more difficult than expected.  Luckily for me I have plenty of experience with basic network setup, as I think most people would find router port forwarding to be a confusing subject.  HooToo provides a link on the bottom of the camera that works specifically with the unit we purchased.  You simply pick a port (8080 is suggested), configure the port forwarding on your router, and I had it working relatively quickly over my laptop on an external network.  No problems internally, either, via tablet or telephone.  I deducted half a star from five, as the CD provided contained set up software for half a dozen camera models, with a labyrinth of a directory structure in order to find the software required for this camera setup.The real problem came when we started leaving the house the day after Christmas, and found that none of our garage door remotes would work.  With six remotes and two openers all malfunctioning in the same fashion, it was clear to me that something substantial in the environment had changed;  too big a coincidence that both openers started failing, not to mention six different remotes.  A little Googling of interference issues with our opener uncovered problems caused by too much RF interference from these cameras (several models of HooToo cameras).  Following recommendations from other individuals that had solved these problems, I fashioned a card board box around the camera and papered it with tin foil.  This resolved the RF interference issue, no thanks to HooToo.  I deducted another 2.5 stars due to this RF interference problem and the steps required to resolve it.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic cameras and even better tech support!
Reviews.Author: robert m. phillips
Reviews.Content: The cameras exceeded our expectations. A little dificulty setting them up but contacted Tech Support and they actually remotely installed them for us and couldn't have been more courteous. The tech, Raymond, was knowledgeable, courteous, patient, and did everything to help get the cameras set up. Even entered all the pertinent info I needed for reference purposes on my Microsoft Excel page. Outstanding! Thanks Raymond for your assistance and thanks to Hoo Too for a quality product.

Reviews.Title: There are much better and simpler to use products on the market.
Reviews.Author: Banquero
Reviews.Content: I bought this with the intention of monitoring my apartment while I was away. After hours of trying to set this thing up I gave up and went to Target to buy a Belkin camera and had the Belkin up and running in minutes. I returned the HooToo camera the very next day.There are Pros to the HooToo camera hardware:-The night vision worked well-The motion detection worked well-the camera would turn to follow you if you walked in front of it-The video quality was fine, and I could view over my home network (but if I am at home why would I need to look at a camera? I need it to work over the internet when I am away from home)The Cons however were just too much-If you know alot about IP and security cameras you could probably figure some of this stuff out by why should you need to? There are other products that are so much simpler, why hassle with this one.-The instructions were written in poor English and were not very helpful-When you try to use one of the 3rd party DDNS providers they are links to Chinese websites.Bottom line, if your a techie person maybe you could save some money by buying this and it'll be fine for you. I consider myself fairly tech saavy and I could not get it to work properly wirelessly (it did work properly over the wired, but I had to be at home for it to work and that defeats the purpose). The Belkin camera was so much easier to work with, take it out of the box connect it to network, download the app, and your done. No messing with IPs or DDNS or chinese instructions. It even has audio and it can send you emails with snapshots when motion is detected. My poor review is based on the fact that this camera is overly difficult to setup compared to competitors. Save yourself the headache

Reviews.Title: not reliable
Reviews.Author: Robert Ross
Reviews.Content: It is almost impossible to set this up on your own. Tech support was very good but had to do it via remote control of my computer. However, the link to the camera both on my computer and mobile constantly went down and had to be manually re-linked. It also sucks up a lot of bandwith effectly other wireless devices at home

Reviews.Title: A good security camera with a lot of features but advanced setup can be confusing!
Reviews.Author: jjceo

logTag.type = "text/javascript"; logTag.src = "/gp/customer-media/du/log.html?ie=UTF8&p=CustomerImage&s=CustomerVideoPlay"; head[0].appendChild(logTag); } if (cv_moKF6A5IIQ0V9FcurrentClick) { return cv_moKF6A5IIQ0V9FcurrentClick(); } } } Length:: 6:38 MinsThis is an extremely powerful security camera that can be connected in the wired Ethernet mode or in a WIFI mode. It has many powerful features that you don't usually find in a security camera in this price range. It is not perfect however but it is very good. I have listed below a list of pros and cons of the unit and I have attached a video of the camera and I point out the product's features. I hope the video is helpful for you.Pros:* Basic installation is fast and simple.* Motorized pan (320°) and tilt (120°) functions that can be controlled remotely.* Wireless and wired network options.* Good price for all of the features.* Good instruction manual on the supplied software disk.* Multiple user settings for visitor, operator and administrator.* You can use Internet Explorer, Safari, Firefox, Google Browser, opera browser or your mobile phone but only the Internet Explorer mode with ActiveX allows you to play video, stop video, record video, use audio or talk modes. You will only be able to take snapshots with the other browsers.* The software can handle 1, 4, or 9 cameras on one screen.* You can add on screen displays of text and date and time for security videos.* Infra-Red night vision capability.* The ability to remote view what the camera is seeing from anywhere in the world using a browser.* The ability to sense noise or motion and alert you via emails with photos of what is going on. You can adjust the sensitivity to motion.* The ability to talk to your family or to an intruder using your remote computer and Internet Explorer.Cons:* Advanced installation is too complicated for the average computer user.* Low quality camera with 640 x 480 pixels but OK for the price. I even had blurred videos in a well lit room. The instruction manual states that the camera should not be manually focused.* You have to enable the ActiveX functions in Internet Explorer and once I did I got continuous warnings regarding possible security issues when using these settings.* Indoor use onlyWhat's in the box?* Camera* Antenna* Mounting adapter* Ethernet cable* Instruction manual* CD with software and a more detailed instruction manual* Mounting screws and hardwareOverall this is a good camera but not great. I have a video surveillance system on my home and I am used to using computerized recording software and night vision cameras. I found the video quality of this camera to be blurry in a well-lit room shooting a person 10 feet away. I also found the advanced set up of the camera to be too complicated for the average computer user. This is one of my major complaints. To get the full functionality of the camera and software you have to use Microsoft Internet Explorer. Using other browsers is possible but you cannot use the record, save and other functions using the other browsers.Using Windows Internet Explorer and getting all of the features requires you to open up access to ActiveX and as a result I got continuous warnings on my screen that my computer was vulnerable to attack because of these settings. This is not exactly a comfortable feeling for the average user. I was using Windows 7 Professional 64 bit Operating System.I rate this product as a 4 star item.I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation and I promised to provide a fair and honest review.

Reviews.Title: A very versatile camera for home or office
Reviews.Author: J. Chambers
Reviews.Content: The Quick Installation Guide that comes with the camera will get you through the basic setup, but before beginning the installation, I highly recommend going to the HooToo website and downloading the full user manual for the HT-IP210F camera. It's much more detailed, with illustrations and screenshots that cover the complete process of installing and using the camera.Installing the camera to work with my home wireless network was very straightforward and only took a few minutes, including installing the IP camera tool from the CD that was packaged with the camera. The next phase was to be able to access the camera from the Internet. That involved changing some of the settings on my Linksys wireless router. I was a little antsy about this, so I emailed the HooToo tech support, and to their credit, I received an answer within a couple of hours.With the camera set up, now I'm playing around with some of the features like the motion detector and audio connection. I've seen enough already to be very impressed with the HT-IP210F. With VGA graphics (640x480), you won't confuse this with an HD camera, but for surveillance purposes, it's fine. I'm only using one camera, but the user manual covers how to add more cameras to the system. One feature I really like is the ability to set and recall up to 15 preset views. This allows you to see a large area quickly without having to pan and tilt the camera. The camera lens is wide angle, so it's in focus from a few inches to infinity. I'm intrigued with all of the possible uses for the camera, from video surveillance and motion detection as part of a home security system to baby monitoring to just keeping an eye on the kids and pets while you're away. It's going to be fun trying out the different applications.Note: I installed the camera software on a PC running Windows 8 and a Chrome browser.A product sample was provided by the manufacturer for review purposes.

Reviews.Title: Worked great for awhile, but now the infrared is not working
Reviews.Author: SD Family of 5 "SD"
Reviews.Content: When I bought the HooToo, I would have rated it a 4 star because it worked great (I used it to check on our toddler in her crib without having to walk in the room and disturb her).  If the software was Mac OS compatible, I would have given it 5 stars, but the setup was a bit of a pain.  Once setup, it worked great and could be viewed from the iPhone.  Unfortunately, the infrared stopped working and no amount of resetting the device would fix it.  Since we used it to check on our toddler while she was sleeping, the infrared was critical, making it pretty much useless for us now.  I still give it 2 stars because it lasted long enough not to be a total bust.

Reviews.Title: decent cam for the money; features a bit primitive; problems with Windows 8
Reviews.Author: xgrep "xgrep"
Reviews.Content: This camera has fairly good quality image and the controls allowed me to set it up more or less the way I need. However, I would've liked a bit more control over, for example, how long it captured images after motion detection, the possibility to capture video, etc. It's interesting how varied are the features of all of the cams out there (I also own an old Panasonic and an Axis, and they're both completely different in what they can do).So this cam leaves a lot to be desired in its features, but the good image quality and acceptable features make it good value.UPDATE:I haven't been able to get the activex control working on Windows 8. It keeps complaining about unsigned publisher, and no matter how low I set security, it still rejects the control. It's really annoying, because there are things that you can't do from Mac OS. If anyone knows how to get this cam to work with a Windows 8 device, please let me know. I won't lower my rating, but it's something people should be aware of.

Reviews.Title: Very nice device;  a little experience needed
Reviews.Author: Les
Reviews.Content: * Hardware seems to be very well done, with good picture quality, and a wide range of motion.* The setup is straight-forward, but it helps to have some knowledge of routers, IP reservations, port forwarding, etc.* Wireless antenna is very good.  Works well from a fair distance (25 ft / 8m) across the house.* Video stream is accessible from either PC or mobile phone.  Very nice feature.* The DDNS is supplied by the manufacturer, so the web stream is not within the user's control.  If you have privacy concerns, this should be further researched.* A surprisingly good camera for the price.

Reviews.Title: Good Product
Reviews.Author: apk
Reviews.Content: Hootoo IP210F looked interesting considering the feature list. However, I was skeptical buying one as it wasn't available in any of the renowned brick-n-mortar stores to visit them, view and gather information. But then I ordered it thinking that I would add few more later once I have first hand experience.On opening the pack the product looks nice. I use it with WiFi and that setup was easy. Changed the settings to trigger on motion detection, as well as continuous recording. Video capture is decent quality (when compared to HD) and tried 2 way audio as well. Overall, a good camera for video surveillance.I wanted to order IP210HD but it was on the higher side so I ordered 2 more IP210F and will add couple of IP210HD once the price drops.There are few aspects of this ip camera that I would like Hootoo to improve1. Unsigned ActiveX control introduce security risk (browser security settings need to be disabled)2. Key camera features are available in IE only3. Video recordings happen when IE/ActiveX is running. Could be implemented as a service (background process).4. Audio Noise in 2 way mode5. Software shows max 9 camera views (not sure if there are any other settings to scale them to 64 as the product description mentions)

Reviews.Title: Just like the other IR cut PT IP cams, at a great price
Reviews.Author: watah
Reviews.Content: My only complaint is that you can not shut off the IR LEDs in a dark room. I tried through the web interface and through softwares, but no luck. If that were fixed I'd give it a 5.This camera is snappy, looks cool and is very simple to set up if you have an understanding of home networking. The wireless signal is strong, the camera is responsive and handles anything an equivalent Foscam can. You can even use their profiles in NVR softwares.I changed the lens on 2 of these to accommodate a wider field of view and I would love to be able to slow the exposure and kill the IR LEDs. This would let me record through my window at my door/car at night. Otherwise I'm considering the optical dome camera they sell and finding a way to mount it outside. It's really awesome the money you can save with these cams and a network recording device. Similar quality costs way more as a package.PS I highly encourage taking a few minutes and focusing the lens manually (grip the rim and twist while monitoring,) makes a big difference in focus distance and image quality.

Reviews.Title: Very Good Surveillance Camera for the Price
Reviews.Author: Dr. Bojan Tunguz
Reviews.Content: A couple of years ago I've bought my first pan/tilt IP camera. These devices have come considerably down in cost, and now you can pretty much cover your entire house with decent surveillance equipment for just a few hundred dollars. However, managing these devices is still tricky, and I would not recommend it to people who are a bit more technically challenged.The trickiest thing about this IP camera is, just like with every other IP camera I've ever worked with, the setup. I am one of those people who tend not to read instruction manuals when setting up a new piece of equipment, but when it comes to IP cameras, you absolutely MUST read and follow all the instructions very, very closely. I re-learned this fact with this camera.One of the things that I really like about this camera is that it's software is compatible with all major web browsers, and hence it's (at least in principle) accessible on any device from anywhere. However, for the full functionality you still have to use Internet Explorer on a Windows computer. This includes the two-way audio and the video recording. I am predominantly a Mac user, and this is a bit of a setback for me. Fortunately, though, I still have an old Windows machine lying around, which I use exactly for these sorts of situations.The pan and tilt work perfectly, and without a glitch. The web interface is very responsive, and the camera changes its position almost instantaneously when I use the motion controls.The resolution and the picture quality are OK for the basic surveillance purposes. However, the picture can be a bit blurry, especially in the low light and compared to what we are accustomed now from our basic mobile devices.The reason that I am giving this product five stars despite its shortcomings is that it's still the best IP camera with this functionality that I've tested. I currently own and use a Motorola baby monitor camera, a D-Link camera, and a Foscam camera. They all have pan and tilt, two-way audio, remote access, night vision and basic VGA resolution. D-Link and Motorola have tried making the camera setup more intuitive and streamlined for the average user, but have instead made a mess of things to the point that under certain configurations you can't even use their products. Neither one of those cameras is very flexible and reliable when working with a wide-variety of web browsers. Foscam cameras, on the other hand, are pretty close in quality to this HooToo camera, but I still think that the HooToo camera has noticeably better picture quality, both in terms of clarity as well as the lack of spherical distortions.This is far from perfect home surveillance camera, but in terms of its price and compared to most of its competitors, I think that HooToo camera is the best option for most regular users.

Reviews.Title: BETTER than our Foscam!!
Reviews.Author: MN Fam
Reviews.Content: Folks, this camera may only be average in spec on paper, but the GUI (software built into camera) is much, much better.  And that makes all the difference in ability to use these things!  The HOOTOO interface looks and feels professionally designed whereas others seem to be from yesteryear.The camera had no issues with setup and seamlessly brought on our Foscam as a secondary.  We not only gained a camera, our whole experience is upgraded.Motor is quiet and fast and there are options to turn off external LEDs.  (Internal green will glow a bit in white model.)

Reviews.Author: W. Sarbach
Reviews.Content: Very good, but the alarm by Email is a little to much got on sensitive 1  / 80 EmailsCamera works perfect !

Reviews.Title: same as 212 crap
Reviews.Author: Susan Barkman
Reviews.Content: this is no different than 212 replaced once sent back second time got my money back. had it in an enclosed porch clean and dry. it was cold at the time but same as the other had to reset several times a day.

Reviews.Title: excellent wireless camera with practical features
Reviews.Author: Nelson
Reviews.Content: This ht-ip210f came in a very good package. The camera itself is milky white and nice-looking. Also very easy to get it set up.Before testing the camera, I looked over the user manual briefly. Just like what other reviewers mentioned, it IS quite lengthy and poorly written with broken English. But as for persons with savvy networking knowledge, this shouldn't be a real problem at all.To start with wired connection, I powered it on and used the included RJ45 Ethernet cable to connect the camera with my Verizon fios' router. Then I ran the IP Cam setup wizard in the disk to create an IP searching tool shortcut on my laptop screen. No software installation problem with my Win7 32bit system. Double click the shortcut and a small window popped out, automatically showing the LAN IP address, something like 10.0.x.x. No manual operation is required to locate the IP address.The next thing is easy as a piece of cake. Double click the selected ip address to get into a web viewing interface. NO password is needed on the login page, which might be a minor safety concern for some people. Personally, I'd rather spare some time and set up the password in Users Settings of the system menu.Everything was just fine and easy with wired connection. I went on to test the wireless connection. Just list out the steps I did and hope they could be of some help:1) While still in wired-working mode, go to network - wireless lan settings page;2) Click "Scan" (maybe nothing shows up). Wait for a minute or two. Click "Scan" again and you should be seeing all your routers listed;3) Select the SSID and submit;4) While it is restarting, unplug the Ethernet cable; the camera should be connected wirelessly to your router;5) Close your IE browser and re-run the ip camera tool to log in again6) You should be able to view the camera video nowOverall, I am very happy with this purchase - it's quite affordable, well-built, nicely-packaged, and everything works just fine for me, except the poorly-written manual. Unlike other reviewers, I don't think I can really complain about this camera. After all, as far as I can get a working product, the manual is useless. Actually I threw away that manual shortly after I tested the camera. Despite some minor issues, such as some features of the cam are unavailable for non-IE browsers, ht-ip210f is actually highly recommended for tech-savvy persons if you consider its price and the features the cam can offer.

Reviews.Title: Don't waste your time
Reviews.Author: Yasmin
Reviews.Content: This is the second IP camera I've ordered from Amazon. I don't know what made me want to try this new one, and I certainly do regret it. It looks nice and everything, with the exception of the power supply which has visable defects along the seams and an a non-working power indicator, but in the end it never worked, and I returned it.Below are the reasons.First of all, my DVD drive couldn't read the disc. The DVD in my laptop works fine, and has never had a problem with any other CDs or DVDs. Anyway, I tried it on an external drive, with the same problem. Empty disc? Strange unknown read issue? I don't know, and it wasn't a great way to get started. I emailed the customer service and received a standard email that advised me to go to a website to download the drivers and software. At first, I was thrilled. Then I tried to access the website and it came up with the unwelcome "page can not be displayed" deal. Different browser? Still couldn't open. Computer at work? Nope.At this point I was pretty angry, and figured I'd better call them directly, as my patience was running out. The phone number provided seems to ring indefinately. This would have been such a simple problem to solve, if someone, at some point, had just checked to see simple things like whether the CD's have problems, or the online site is working, or that there is an easy way to reach customer support.It's unreasonable to me that a company who makes security products business provides such an unstable product and support. I considered the fact that maybe I just got a defective unit, but that still doesn't excuse the sketchy customer service. Maybe I was expecting too much.Don't waste your time on this camera - the customer service and quality control are simply unacceptable; In the end I was glad to return it.

Reviews.Title: Works great
Reviews.Author: C. Applegate "Hazmat"
Reviews.Content: Took a few minutes to figure out the port forwarding on the router but after that the camera worked great. Emails come instantly and my phone has no problem accessing the camera. Great value for the price.

Reviews.Title: Works ao far
Reviews.Author: Beau A. Davis "Marine"
Reviews.Content: I just set it all up and seems do work, took a little tinkering while reading the manual, but its doable, i would recommend haveing a little knowlegde on routing and routers!

Reviews.Title: Excellent
Reviews.Author: G. Levin
Reviews.Content: I'm pleasantly surprised with this IP camera.  It works well and has a huge pan and tilt range. It gives a clear view in almost total darkness too. I can monitor my home via WiFi, 3G, 4g and LTE on my iPhone and iPad from anywhere. It was shipped very quickly, and the price was right.Update - I have owned it for more than a year with no problems. I originally had it wired to my router, and have since used it in wireless mode. It works well either way. Recently I wanted to change Dynamic DNS providers, and contacted HooToo for an update to the Device Embedded Web UI that included an option for the provider that I wanted. They replied in one day, and sent me the file that I needed. Great service as well as a great product.HooToo HT-IP210F Wired/Wireless WiFi Network Camera, 16-LEDs (Night Vision) Extended Survey Area, Pan/Tilt (Horizontal:320° & Vertical: 120°), Built-in Mic & Speaker for Two-Way Audio Communication, Embedded IR Filter for Much Real Colors, Free DDNS Lin...

Reviews.Title: It isn’t HD, but it is clear. Speaker and microphone functionality is a great plus, but I wasn’t able to get speaker working.
Reviews.Author: Charles Spanky "Zumina Reviews"
Reviews.Content: Nowadays, security cameras have been essential for both businesses and residential. Having the security of knowing what is happening at all times is a great comfort having. HooToo has made the HooToo® HT-IP210F Wireless IP Network Surveillance Camera as a way to maintain a secure atmosphere.▶ Package Contents• IP Camera• Wi-Fi Antenna• User manual• DC power supply cord• CD Rom• Ethernet cord• Mounting Bracket• 4 mounting screws with drywall inserts▶ Accessories (Needs DC Power cord length and mounting bracket updated)The Ethernet cord is 56 inches with a thick gauged wire. Although the cord is short, this is definitely one of the better built Ethernet cords I own. The Ethernet cord will do what it is intended for and help setup the IP camera.The DC power cord is 57 inches with a 2.75 x 1 x 1.5 inch brick at the end of the cord. I would normally name this a con, because it would block neighboring outlets, but I would expect this cord to be attached to some sort of extension cord and not a surge protector.The mounting bracket has a 4 x 4 circular platform, with a 20 threaded screw that goes into the center of the bottom of the camera. This platform is guided by a 3 inch arm, which is almost able to maneuver in a little over 90°. On the bottom of the bracket is the 3.75 x 1.5 platform that can screw into a wall. The mounting bracket is very nice if you need to place your camera in a position that is other than up-right.▶ Specifications• Powerful high-speed video protocol processor• High-sensitivity ¼” CMOS sensor• Picture total 300k pixels• Support PT control, Pan 320°, Tilt 120°• Optimized MJPEG video compression for transmission• Multi-level users management and passwords definition• Embedded web server for users to visit by IE• Support wireless network (WI-FI/802.11/b/g)• Supporting Dynamic IP (DDNS) and UPNP LAN and Internet (ADSL, Cable Modem)• Giving Alarm in case of motion detection• Supporting image snapshot• Support multiple protocols: HTTP/TCP/IP/UDP/SMTP/DDNS/SNTP/DHCP/FTP• Support WEP/WPA/WPA2 encryption• Support 3G phone, Smart phone control and surveillance• Support Firefox, Safari, Google Chrome browser▶ HardwareThe camera is a little bigger than today’s webcams (8.3 x 4.9 x 6.6 inches; 2 pounds), with a matt black or white plastic design. The front has the lens, light sensitive censor, 10 infrared LEDs, network indicator LED, and microphone. The right side has the speaker, and back has the RJ-45 (Ethernet) port, Wi-Fi antenna, 5V power socket, audio output, alarm I/O pins, microphone output, reset button, and SD card port. The bottom has the specifications and threaded hole for the mounting bracket. Overall, this is an all-in-one camera that seems to have everything it should have.▶ Software SetupHooToo provides two pieces of software for this device “IP Camera Tool” and “IPCamClient”. Don’t worry if you are initially confused, because I was. After reading the manual, “IP Camera Tool” is the only tool required. Follow the following directions to install your camera:1. Install the “IP Camera Tool” and then restart your computer.2. Plug your DC power supply into your camera and power your device.3. Wait approximately 30 seconds for your device to be read4. Open the “IP Camera Tool” Program5. You should see “Anonymous” and “Subnet doesn’t match, double click to change!”6. Check the box “Obtain IP from DHCP Server” This will automatically setup your device that is connected to your router. If you want to change the user/password and HTTP Port then feel free to.7. Your device should be connected. Congratulations. Now, you will be redirected to a website that you can view your camera. If you want to make this device wireless then continues to step 8.8. After you are on your website i.e 192.168.0.12/main.htm, enter username “admin” and password blank (nothing here), click the Network tab and then “Wireless Lan Settings”.9. Click the Scan button under “Wireless Network List”10. Choose your network, key, and then click the submit button.11. Congratulations, you should now be able to use your camera wirelessly!▶ SoftwareThe website includes tabs for “Live Video, Multi-Device, Network, Audio Video, System, and Other”.• Live video- Self explanatory• Multi-Device- Upgrade device firmware, restore to factory settings, or reboot device. I would assume this would be used for multi-camera view, but it is instead used for factory settings.• Network- Basic network settings, wireless LAN settings, ADSL settings, UPnP settings, DDNS Service settings• Audio video- Reversal, mirror. This has no audio settings, but may have settings when an audio source is connected.• System- Device settings, alias settings, Date and Time settings, User settings, PT Settings, (LED) indicator settings, backup and restore settings, log, and MSN settings. Nothing really to note here other than it includes “MSN Settings”; an instant massaging program that has been discontinued since 2013.• Other – Mail service settings, FTP server settings, Alarm settings. I like that this includes settings for FTP and mail services so you can always be updated of the images from your work.Under the vertical tabs are options to change “Resolution, Mode, Bright, and Contrast”.• Resolution – 160 x 120, 320 x 240, 640 x 480• Mode – 50 Hz, 60 Hz, Outdoor• Bright – 0 to 15• Contrast – 0 to 6Under that is a circular compass to move the camera whichever direction you want. Under the compass are 8 buttons.• Set preset position• Call preset position• Zoom in• Zoom out• Horizon Patrol• Stop Horizon Patrol• Switch on• Switch offAt the right top is an option to take a “Snapshot” image of the live camera feed. Although the website doesn’t look very appealing, it is very functional for the purpose of the camera. There are other supplemental software choices, such as Blue Iris, which use a very intuitive design, and give audio functionality, which the website doesn’t provide, for compatible devices such as this one, but cost extra money. These supplemental pieces of software, however, do not provide full functionality that the website provides, such as horizontal, vertical patrol, and setting one of the nine preset positions. Whether you like it or not, you will need to use the website at least a few times.▶ TestingI placed this camera in the kitchen, which is also the location of one of the entries of the house, for about a week. During this time, I noticed the camera did go offline a few times, which required me to reset the IP address of the camera, however these problems were very minimal. The picture is only 640 x 480, which isn’t HD by any means, but you can make out images clearly; whether it would be in light or night vision. I have yet to see a reason for using the full pan and tilt features, unless I would be using this for business purposes. As said in software, you would not be able to hear the audio through the website, instead you would need to use supplemental software, such as Blue Iris to listen to your IP camera. The audio on this camera, using Blue Iris, was very clear. I could literally hear a pin drop from the next room. Unfortunately though, as of today, I have not figured out how to use the speaker that is included on the side of the camera. I would like to use this as an intercom system, since the camera has a speaker and microphone, but have yet to see this function. In the end, if you’d be using this as a baby or child monitor, you would be able to tell if your children were in danger.▶ Final ThoughtsThe camera is very functional. It is able to listen and monitor images clearly, but it isn’t HD clear. If you are looking for an IP camera that can see individual hairs on your back then I’d suggest looking elsewhere, however, if you are looking for a security camera or baby monitor that performs well, then I would definitely recommend this camera. Because of the functionality and performance, I give this IP camera a 5 star rating. My only room for improvement would be for the included speaker to function, but I don’t find it a necessity.Pros:+ Able to be used during daytime or nighttime, with the ability to+ Includes several options such as presets, zoom in and out, and horizon patrol. These are great functional settings that optimize the camera’s capabilities.+ Includes options for FTP and mail service so you can monitor your home while you are at work.+ Antenna is able to bend in 360 degree motion to give the best Wi-Fi connection.Cons:- Could not get included speaker to function.- Software design is functional but is frustrating to use and isn’t very aesthetically pleasing; it is preferred to use supplemental software, which can be an additional cost.I was provided a sample in exchange for a thorough and honest review.

Reviews.Title: Great product! Best price!
Reviews.Author: Ely
Reviews.Content: Ok, I don't really write reviews but after I tried few cameras already I want to express my thoughts about hootoo. I tried best reviews piece of crp Dropcam HD. It's useless, don't buy this junk: very slow and delay is 5-10secs- no way you can use it real time, no motorized control either, and you need internet and lots of traffic. Also it crashed so many times! Hootoo is the best: it's cheap, reliable, has all features I need! It's really a professional piece of equipment. It works locally so you won't slow down internet traffic etc, and you can set it up to watch through inet as well. I use it as a baby monitor and it's great!! Presets are awesome and iphone all is great. This camera can see everything in the room thanks to motorized control. Setting up is very easy if you can read English instructions, so pls don't complain about very complicated setup and blah blah. Product is very good and does it's job every day, compared to overrated dropcam junk, which crashed and froze on me so many times!!! Now I need to get rid of fancy design dropcam junk.

Reviews.Title: Good affordable IP Camera
Reviews.Author: Awkward Hamster
